}} 'Maturity onset diabetes of the young' ('MODY') refers to any of
several hereditary forms of diabetes caused by mutations in an autosomal
dominant gene (sex independent,
i.e. inherited from any of the parents) disrupting insulin production. MODY is
often referred to as "'monogenic diabetes'" to distinguish it from the more
common types of diabetes (especially type 1 and type 2), which involve more
complex combinations of causes involving multiple genes (i.e., "polygenic") and
environmental factors. MODY 2 and MODY 3 are the most common forms. "Maturity
onset diabetes of the young (MODY) is a rare autosomal dominant form of type 2
DM affecting young people with a positive family history." This page has
previosuly claimed that MODY is equivalent to type 1 DM, however the Oxford
Handbook of Clinical Medicine states the above. MODY should not be
confused with latent autoimmune diabetes of adults (LADA) â€” a form of type
1 DM, with slower progression to insulin dependence in later life.
